bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jessie Daniel Ames, August 23, 1950

div1.p: Hench describes the difficulties he has encountered in memorializing Camp Lazear. He discusses where he believes his collection should eventually be stored, citing the Mayo Foundation, the University of Virginia's Alderman Library, and the National Archives. He does not want the items to be in Cuba.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jessie Daniel Ames, August 23, 1950
div1.opener:
August 23, 1950
Mrs. Jessie Daniel Ames
The Wren's Nest
Tryon, North Carolina
My dear Mrs. Ames:
div1.p:
I am glad to have your letter of August 12 and I have been interested
to read of your reaction toward your possession of the yellow fever charts.
Actually, that was my own feeling, that these charts do not belong to anyone
individual and I was surprised that the Surgeon General's Office did not re-
quest the return of those years ago from your husband.

I agree with you that they belong to the nation and should be made
available to historians and students of the conquest of yellow fever and the
lives of those concerned. That is why I have not accepted any of the hundreds
of items that have been given to me as personal gifts. I am merely the tem-
porary custodian until such time as more proper and permanent disposition can
be made.

I have had all sorts of set-backs with regard to the little memorial
museum which we had hoped to build in Cuba on the site of Camp Lazear. As
you know, I made several trips there. My plans were interrupted by the war
but about two years ago I went to Cuba again and spent a couple of weeks there.
During this time, I interviewed various public health officers, the secretary of defense
and the members of the Engineering and Building Department and the Vice President.
They all received me most cordially and accepted plans which I had drawn up. As
a result of previous visits of mine they had finally designated Building No. 1
a national monument but I found that they had done nothing to protect it.
I offered the Vice President a sum of money and asked if he would allow me
to at least put a protecting covering around the building. With typical
Latin-American vehemence he protested that the Cuban Government could not possibly
let me spend my own money but that they would protect the little building. I saw
the owners of the land around the building and they said that they were as help-
less as I since the building itself is a national monument. However after my
visit the Cuban government did allot $50,000 and pass a bill to initiate pro-
tection of Building No. 1 and carry out my preliminary plans but most regret-
fully I must tell you that within a few months that administration went out,
a new one came in and what happened to the $50,000 is anyone's guess. Nothing
has been done. However I have been corresponding with Johnny Moran and there are
a few other Americans who are interested in the project and we have tried some
how or other to proceed but probably we will have to raise all the money in this
country.

In view of the constant delay by the Cubans, I do not believe that
they deserve to have the enormous amount of material I have collected not only
from you but the families of all the survivors, including the Reed family.
Mrs. Jessie Daniel Ames
- 2 -
August 23, 1950
Three institutions are very anxious to have the material. The Mayo Foundation
is willing to set aside a special room for its display in the new library of
the new Mayo Clinic which has just been started. The advantage of having it
preserved by the Mayo Foundation would be that many thousands of doctors would
see the material each year whereas if it were put elsewhere a very small number
would see it. The University of Virginia Library (where Reed graduated) also
wants the collection and last year when I visited the National Archives in
Washington, the curator who knew of this collection asked whether I would con-
sider sending it there. I have sought and received much advice on this point
from many, including the Reed and Lazear families, General Kean and others and
it now seems best to have the material preserved in one place but allow the
other institutions who wish the material to have microfilmed copies of all the
data. In this way all will be satisfied, and from the standpoint of safety,
the records or copies of the records, will be not in one place but in several
places. It is my plan therefore not to give the little Cuban museum (if it
ever materializes) the originals but merely copies which will suffice. I hesitate
greatly to trust the originals to the Cubans. There is no purpose in
returning the fever charts to the Surgeon General as long since their old records
have been sent to the National Archives. I regret to say that here they are
scattered in hundreds of places and it is extremely difficult for anyone to
find them. I have spent as long as two weeks at a time in Washington, getting
each day pitiably small collections as we traced down one file after another.
Ordinarily the National Archives would be the place for all of this material
but in view of what I have just said, I and some of my advisors have serious
doubts.

Rest assured that the material which I hold merely as a trustee is
being taken care of. Much of it is in safe deposit boxes, including your
fever charts and it will be preserved in toto, the choice not being made by
me alone but with the advice of the Walter Reed Association and the families
of those most concerned.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
P.S.: Did you know that Mrs. Walter Reed died a month ago?
